evidence_items.text: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The tug instructor pulled the aircraft forward off the fence then stopped the tug.

The airport operator and ATC were notified. Soon after, representatives from the airport operator and the RFFS were on scene. The aircraft sustained substantial damage to the rear of the aircraft, including the APU, which was running at the time.
The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback. The first was completed earlier that day, without event.

roots_spec.exclusion_clause: Not explained by any other root
Not explained by any other root
Not explained by any other root
Not explained by any other root

slot_statements.availability: Communication/coordination breakdown among crew is evident in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25 as documented in hist_t2_interim.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The explanation of communication/coordination breakdown among crew in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 incident is resistant to defeaters, as alternative causes have been ruled out in hist_t2_interim.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 incident, including miscommunication and lack of coordination.

node.statement: Communication/coordination breakdown among crew is evident in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25 as documented in hist_t2_interim.

defeaters: If evidence showed clear, effective communication and timely warnings from all crew members preventing the incident
If the incident was caused by mechanical failure unrelated to crew communication

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence shows communication channels existed (H1), and some coordination occurred (H2, H3), but the tug instructor noted the visual stop signal was insufficient and no warnings were received from other crew (H8). The aircraft overran the TRP and hit a barrier (H4), indicating a breakdown in effective communication/coordination among crew.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No direct transcripts or recordings of crew communication during the incident; reliance on post-event statements and observations

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 incident, including miscommunication and lack of coordination.

assumptions: That the lack of warnings and insufficient signals imply miscommunication and coordination breakdown
That the trainee handing over control reflects coordination issues
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, effective communication and coordination among crew during pushback
If the collision was caused by factors unrelated to crew communication or coordination

quotes.exact_quote: The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence shows some communication and coordination issues among the tug crew, such as the trainee stopping and handing over control (H2), the instructor advising the trainee while pushing back (H3), and the tug instructor noting insufficient visual signals and lack of warnings from other crew (H8), indicating miscommunication and coordination breakdown consistent with the claim.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No direct evidence explicitly describing miscommunication or coordination failures; interpretations are inferred from crew actions and statements.

node.statement: The explanation of communication/coordination breakdown among crew in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 incident is resistant to defeaters, as alternative causes have been ruled out in hist_t2_interim.

assumptions: The absence of warnings from wingman and headset operator implies no alternative communication failures were present.
Qualification and awareness of the trainee imply that human error was not due to lack of knowledge.
defeaters: If new evidence showed alternative causes for the breakdown, such as equipment failure or external interference, this would change the assessment.

quotes.exact_quote: The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback. The first was completed earlier that day, without event.

outcome.reasoning_summary: The evidence indicates that communication methods (visual signals) were insufficient and no warnings were given by other crew members (H8), and the trainee was qualified and aware of procedures (H9), suggesting alternative causes were considered and ruled out, supporting resistance to defeaters.
outcome.uncertainty_source: lack of explicit evidence directly ruling out all alternative causes; reliance on inference from crew statements.

slot_statements.availability: The environmental or marking deficiency must be present and identifiable in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the hist_t2_interim period on 12-25.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The identification of the environmental or marking deficiency must be robust against potential counterarguments or evidence that could negate its presence or significance in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the hist_t2_interim period.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The environmental or marking deficiency should align with the key features and characteristics relevant to the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA model and its operational context during the hist_t2_interim timeframe.

node.statement: The environmental or marking deficiency must be present and identifiable in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the hist_t2_interim period on 12-25.

defeaters: Evidence showing a marking or environmental deficiency present and identifiable on the aircraft or at the TRP during the specified period.
outcome.reasoning_summary: No evidence indicates the presence or identification of an environmental or marking deficiency on the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the hist_t2_interim period on 12-25; the TRP markings and clearance are described but no deficiency is reported (H4, H7, H8, H9).

slot_statements.availability: The mechanical/control failure in Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA on 12-25 is present and observable in the hist_t2_interim dataset.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The mechanical/control failure is resistant to defeaters and remains valid under scrutiny within the hist_t2_interim dataset for Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA on 12-25.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The mechanical/control failure aligns with the key features identified for Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA on 12-25 in the hist_t2_interim dataset.

node.statement: The mechanical/control failure in Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA on 12-25 is present and observable in the hist_t2_interim dataset.

assumptions: The hist_t2_interim dataset corresponds to the provided history evidence items H1-H9
Mechanical/control failure would be explicitly mentioned or observable in the evidence if present
defeaters: If evidence showed mechanical or control system faults or failures in the aircraft during the incident
If the hist_t2_interim dataset contained data indicating mechanical/control failure
outcome.reasoning_summary: None of the provided history evidence items (H1-H9) mention or indicate any mechanical or control failure in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA on 12-25; the evidence describes a pushback incident involving tug driver actions and aircraft movement but no mechanical/control failure is reported or observable in the hist_t2_interim dataset.

slot_statements.availability: The procedural deviation in pushback execution is documented and available in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t2_interim dataset.

defeaters: If the dataset did not include these detailed history records or if the procedural deviation was not explicitly documented in the dataset.

node.statement: The procedural deviation in pushback execution aligns with the key features identified for the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t2_interim context.

The described signaling method and roles reflect standard procedural features.

outcome.uncertainty_source: No explicit procedural checklist or standard operating procedure text is provided to confirm exact alignment; assumptions are made based on described context and roles.

node.statement: The procedural deviation in pushback execution withstands potential counterarguments and remains valid within the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t2_interim scope.

assumptions: The procedural deviation refers to the actions during pushback as described in the history
The scope 'Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t2_interim' corresponds to the events described in the evidence
defeaters: If evidence showed that the procedural deviation was explicitly against established safety protocols or that effective countermeasures were ignored
If there was proof that the headset operator or wingman gave timely warnings that were disregarded
If the deviation was found to be the sole cause of the accident without mitigating factors

quotes.exact_quote: The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback. The first was completed earlier that day, without event.

outcome.reasoning_summary: The evidence shows that despite the procedural deviation, the tug instructor and trainee followed known communication and operational protocols (H3, H9). The instructor noted limitations in the visual stop signal and lack of warnings from other crew (H8), which supports the validity of the deviation under the circumstances. The aircraft still passed the TRP and hit the blast barrier (H4), indicating the deviation had consequences but was not contradicted by counterarguments.
outcome.uncertainty_source: lack of explicit procedural documentation or counterargument evidence in the provided history

children_spec.statement: Required environmental markings are missing or obscured
children_spec.test_procedure: Inspect the aircraft and surrounding environment for presence and visibility of all required markings; absence or obstruction would lower the probability

children_spec.statement: Environmental conditions prevent proper visibility of markings
children_spec.test_procedure: Evaluate environmental factors such as lighting, weather, and obstructions that could impair visibility of markings; evidence of clear conditions would lower the probability

children_spec.statement: Markings are present but not maintained or are degraded
children_spec.test_procedure: Assess the condition and maintenance records of markings; well-maintained markings would lower the probability

node.statement: Markings are present but not maintained or are degraded

defeaters: Evidence showing markings are present and maintained
Evidence showing markings are present but degraded or not maintained
outcome.reasoning_summary: None of the provided evidence items mention the presence, maintenance, or degradation of markings such as the Tug Release Point (TRP) markings or any other ground markings. The evidence focuses on the pushback operation, personnel actions, and the collision event but does not address marking condition.

children_spec.statement: Mechanical control components are physically present and installed in the aircraft
children_spec.test_procedure: Inspect the aircraft to verify the presence and installation of all mechanical control components

children_spec.statement: Mechanical control components are free from physical damage or obstruction
children_spec.test_procedure: Perform a detailed physical inspection and functional test to detect any damage or obstruction in mechanical control components

children_spec.statement: Mechanical control components are properly connected and linked to control inputs
children_spec.test_procedure: Verify mechanical linkages and connections between control inputs and control surfaces through inspection and functional testing

children_spec.statement: Mechanical control components are not seized or jammed and move freely as intended
children_spec.test_procedure: Manually operate mechanical controls and observe for any seizure, jamming, or restricted movement

node.statement: Mechanical control components are not seized or jammed and move freely as intended

defeaters: Direct inspection or maintenance reports confirming mechanical control component condition
Evidence of mechanical seizure or jamming
Alternative explanations for the aircraft movement beyond TRP

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The aircraft sustained substantial damage to the rear of the aircraft, including the APU, which was running at the time.

outcome.reasoning_summary: The aircraft continued moving beyond the TRP and hit the blast barrier despite the engine being at idle (H4), indicating possible control issues. However, no direct evidence states that mechanical control components were seized or jammed; the movement beyond TRP could be due to other factors. Damage to the aircraft (H6) confirms impact but does not clarify mechanical control status.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No direct evidence on mechanical control component condition; ambiguity whether movement beyond TRP was due to mechanical failure or operational error.

node.statement: Environmental conditions prevent proper visibility of markings

defeaters: Evidence showing poor visibility due to weather, lighting, or other environmental factors affecting marking visibility.
outcome.reasoning_summary: No evidence in the provided history indicates that environmental conditions prevented proper visibility of markings.

children_spec.statement: Crew members were physically present and reachable during the operation
children_spec.test_procedure: Check crew attendance logs, communication device records, and physical presence reports to confirm availability

children_spec.statement: Communication devices and channels were operational and accessible to all crew members
children_spec.test_procedure: Verify maintenance and functionality reports of radios, intercoms, and other communication equipment used by the crew

children_spec.statement: Crew members were not incapacitated or otherwise unable to participate in communication
children_spec.test_procedure: Review medical records, incident reports, and witness statements to determine if any crew member was incapacitated

node.statement: Crew members were physically present and reachable during the operation

assumptions: Physical presence and proximity implied by seating arrangements and described positions near the tug
Reachability inferred from described interactions and observations
defeaters: If evidence showed any crew member was absent or unreachable during the operation
If communication devices failed preventing contact

quotes.exact_quote: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback. The first was completed earlier that day, without event.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1, H3, and H9 confirm crew members (tug instructor, trainee driver, headset operator, wingman) were physically present and reachable during the operation. H8 indicates communication signals were attempted but not always effective, supporting presence but some communication issues.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No explicit statement about physical reachability distance or any crew member being unreachable; some ambiguity in effectiveness of visual signals.

node.statement: Communication devices and channels were operational and accessible to all crew members

defeaters: Evidence showing all crew members received timely and effective communication warnings
Reports of communication device failures or inaccessibility

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles.

outcome.reasoning_summary: While communication devices (interphone) were operational and used (H1), the lack of warnings from wingman or headset operator (H8) and the trainee's limited experience (H9) suggest communication was not fully effective or accessible to all crew, indicating partial availability but not full operational accessibility.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No explicit statements confirming all crew had full access and operational use of communication devices; ambiguity about effectiveness of communication despite device availability.
